summary: Ewing sarcoma is a type of pediatric cancer that forms in bone or soft tissue, most commonly in the legs, pelvis, and chest wall. It is a small round cell sarcoma that affects teenagers and young adults, and is the second most common bone cancer in children and adolescents.
causes: Reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11;22), which fuses the EWSR1 gene with the FLI1 gene
Genetic change known as a reciprocal translocation
risk_factors: Older age at diagnosis (older than 18 years of age)
symptoms: Swelling at the site of the tumor
Pain at the site of the tumor
diagnosis: Conventional radiographs (moth-eaten pattern, Codman triangle, onion peel appearance)
treatments: Multidrug chemotherapy (vincristine, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, ifosfamide, etoposide)
Local disease control with radiation therapy
